tool.name: PICRUSt2 - Hidden state prediction (HSP)
tool.command: hsp.py --tree '$tree' #if $trait_input.selector == "default" --in_trait '$trait_input.in_trait' #else if $trait_input.selector == "custom" --observed_trait_table '$trait_input.observed_trait_table' #end if @HSP_METHOD@ --output '$prediction_output' $calculate_NSTI $check ## not implemented --chunk_size hoping that the default is carefully chosen ## otherwise one might need to compute a "good" value from the number of ## entries in the trait table and the number of available processors -p "\${GALAXY_SLOTS:-1}"

param.label: Newick tree with study sequences placed amongst reference sequences
param.help: The full reference tree containing both study sequences (i.e. ASVs or OTUs) and reference sequences.

param.name: selector
param.label: Argument specifying non-default reference files to use for sequence placement
Default pre-calculated trait table to use
Customized trait table
param.help: Describes directly observed traits (e.g. sequenced genomes) in tab-delimited format.

param.label: Seed to make output reproducible
param.help: is necessary for the emp_prob method

param.label: Calculate NSTI and add to output file
param.help: Indicates that Nearest-sequenced taxon index (NSTI) values should be calculated

param.label: Check input trait table before HSP

tool.help:
@HELP_HEADER@
Hidden State Prediction (HSP) ============================= Performs hidden state prediction on tips in the input tree with unknown trait values. Typically this script is used to predict the copy number of gene families present in the predicted genome for each amplicon sequence variant, given a tree and a set of known trait values. This script outputs a table of trait predictions.
Note ==== Run hidden-state prediction (hsp) to predict gene family abundances.
Input ===== Newick tree with study sequences placed amongst reference sequences.
Output ====== Tabular file containing predicted counts.
